content.text: Use a loop of string to balance the metre rule as shown in Fig. 1.1
Measure and record distance \(k\) between the loop and the end of the rule as shown in Fig. 1.1
Use the other loop of string to attach the mass hanger at a distance \(d\) from the end of the rule as shown in Fig. 1.2. The value of \(d\) should be approximately \(5 \text{cm}\)
For this value of \(d\), adjust the position of the rule so that it balances
The new distance between the first loop and the end of the rule is \(D\), as shown in Fig. 1.2
Measure and record lengths \(d\) and \(D\)
d =
D =
Calculate the value of \(\frac{(D - d)}{D}\)
By moving the mass hanger along the metre rule, repeat **(b)(ii)**, **(b)(iii)** and **(b)(iv)** until you have six sets of values of \(d\) and \(D\)
Include values of \(\frac{1}{D}\) and \(\frac{(D - d)}{D}\) in your table
For
Examiner's
Use
Plot a graph of \(\frac{(D - d)}{D}\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(\frac{1}{D}\) on the \(x\)-axis
Draw the straight line of best fit
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line
gradient =
y-intercept =
The quantities \(d\) and \(D\) are related by the equation
where \(A\) and \(B\) are constants
Use your answers in **(d)(iii)** to determine the value of \(\frac{A}{B}\). Give appropriate units
In this experiment you will investigate the equilibrium position of a metre rule with a mass attached to one end
Measure and record the thickness \(t\) of one of the strips of card
Measure and record the length \(L\) of the same strip of card as shown in Fig. 2.1
Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of \(L\)
percentage uncertainty = .........
Measure and record the width \(w\) of the same strip as shown in Fig. 2.1
w =
Determine the volume \(V\) of the strip, using the equation
Use tape to stick the two strips together, so that they do not overlap, to make the shape shown in Fig. 2.2
Use the pin to make a hole at the top of the vertical strip as shown in Fig. 2.3
The hole should be central and as near to the top as possible and be large enough for the card to swing freely on the pin
Using the cork and pin, suspend the card shape as shown in Fig. 2.4
Move the card shape to the left. Release the shape and watch its movement
The shape will move to the right and then to the left again, completing a swing as shown in Fig. 2.5
The time taken for one complete swing is \(T\)
By timing several of these complete swings, determine an accurate value for \(T\)
Cut both strips so that \(L\) is approximately \(10 \text{cm}\), as shown in Fig. 2.6
Measure and record the length \(L\) of the vertical strip
Repeat (d)(ii), (d)(iii) and (e) for this new shape
Using your data, calculate two values of \(k\)
first value of \(k =\)
second value of \(k =\)
Justify the number of significant figures that you have given for your values of \(k\)
Explain whether your results support the suggested relationship
It is suggested that the relationship between \(T\) and \(L\) for this shape is
where \(k\) is a constant
You may not need to use all of the materials provided
In this experiment you will investigate how the motion of a thin card shape depends on its size
You have been provided with two identical strips of card. Spare strips are available if necessary
